Touchscreens are no longer limited to handheld devices like tablets and smartphones. The fact that many contemporary monitors support touch input may leave users wondering why there is so much unrest about the technology.


Those contemplating purchasing a display with a touch screen should, before doing anything else, consider what they want to accomplish with the device. Although they are helpful for various purposes and applications, touch-enabled displays of the modern day come with a few downsides.

However, these limitations might be more than anyone bargained for, and if this is the case, you should consider looking into the best touchscreen monitors rather than going with an IPS display.


Touchscreens offer a variety of functions that are not found in other interface types and that are quite helpful. However, they may be rather expensive, so if that concerns you, you will need to become familiar with converting a monitor into a touchscreen.

Consider making the investment in a touchscreen monitor after reading the following compelling arguments in favor of doing so: As a result, we can provide you with choices such as Philips, Planar, and Dell.


Touchscreen displays, on the other hand, do not necessitate the usage of a mouse and a keyboard in the same way that standard monitors do. Because of this, they won't take up as much room in your workplace or any other location where you want to put them to use.

You may not be given the luxury of utilizing a conventional monitor if there is a lot of activity in your workplace. Touchscreen displays, on the other hand, don't need a mouse and keyboard to function so you may use them even in more cramped quarters.

2. Planar Helium PCT2785

Planar Helium PCT2785

Beautifully designed monitor featuring touch screen with 20-point capacitive touch.

SPECIFICATIONS

Size: 27-inch

Display: 1920 x 1080


REASONS TO BUY

+ Superb sensitivity to the touch.

+ Consistent hue quality.

+ Ports galore.


REASONS TO AVOID

+ Disruption in the form of touching wires.

+ Acceptable performance in the grayscale.

+ No USB 3.0.

It's no surprise that the advent of Windows 8 has led to a surge in the manufacturing of touchscreen monitors, and now these interactive displays are starting to make their way onto store shelves. A number of 22- and 23-inch touchscreens have been examined, and more are on the way.


The 20-point touch technology included in the Planar Helium PCT2785 makes it the first large-screen touch monitor to arrive at PC Labs since the release of Windows 8. This humongous display uses a Multi-domain Vertical Alignment (MVA) panel measuring 27 inches in diagonal size. MVA panels are distinguished by their high natural contrast ratios (in this example, 5,000:1), vivid color reproduction, and broad viewing angles. It has several different connection options, a built-in camera, and an adjustable stand.


However, it does not do well with grayscale; high-light backgrounds reveal barely discernible vertical lines. Planar Systems' Multi-Touch LCD Monitor provides an appealing touch screen experience. This monitor features a glass surface that extends to the edges and can accommodate up to 10 touchpoints.


This monitor has a capacitive multi-touch monitor, Full HD 1920 x 1080 quality, a contrast ratio of 1000:1, a brightness rating of 250 cd/m2, and wide viewing angles (178 degrees horizontal and vertical).

3. Planar Helium PCT2235

Planar Helium PCT2235

The most bang for your buck may be had by purchasing a full HD display with multi-touch interaction.


SPECIFICATIONS

Size: 22-inch

Display: 1920 x 1080 Full HD 60Hz

+ Interactivity with ten fingers at once

REASONS TO AVOID

+ Utilitarian design.

The Planar PCT2235 touchscreen display is an economical option for productivity tasks because its Projected Capacitive touch technology allows for quick and precise touch control. This LED-backlit LCD monitor with a screen size of 21.5" provides stunning images with a resolution of Full HD and a contrast ratio of 1000:1. Additionally, it has two internal speakers for efficient sound reproduction, eliminating the need for additional speakers to be connected externally.

With three inputs, including VGA, HDMI, and DisplayPort, it is compatible with a wide range of visual devices. The Planar PCT2235's slim black bezel makes it an excellent choice for multi-monitor setups. Its blue light reduction settings allow users to adjust the amount of blue light displayed on the screen based on their current task, reducing eye strain. You'll also like that the stand can be tilted at any angle between 15 and seventy degrees or folded completely flat for use on a tabletop.


The greatest 22-inch Full HD monitor you can buy is the Planar PCT2235, which supports multi-touch input. The monitor's Projected Capacitive touch capability recognizes up to 10 touches at once, making it ideal for graphic artists who can quickly scroll through design iterations or resize photographs and office employees who need to glance through emails fast.

Size

Before making a purchase, think about how big you need your touchscreen monitor to be. Touchscreen monitors may range from a few inches up to 52 inches, as you may have already noticed (and larger). Perhaps a more prominent touchscreen display would be more appropriate for a conference room. A smaller monitor may be enough for usage at individual workstations.


Aspect Ratio


When shopping for a touchscreen display, it's essential to consider the screen's dimensions and capabilities and its aspect ratio. The aspect ratio of a screen is the proportion of its horizontal to vertical dimensions. There was a time when 4:3 was the standard for monitors, but currently, 16:9 is used by the vast majority of displays, including touchscreen monitors.


Touch Technology


All modern displays that you can touch do so with ease. However, how they recognize such orders differs from the touch technology that drives them. Both resistive and capacitive touch technologies are used in modern touchscreen displays.
